greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Let {c(i)} = A007916 denote the sequence of numbers > 1 which are not perfect powers. Every positive integer n has a unique representation as a tower n = c(x_1)^c(x_2)^c(x_3)^...^c(x_k), where the exponents are nested from the right. The sequence is an irregular triangle read by rows, where the n-th row lists n followed by x_1, ..., x_k.
comment: The row lengths are A288636(n) + 1. - _Gus Wiseman_, Jun 12 2017
See A278028 for a version in which row n simply lists x_1, x_2, ..., x_k (omitting the initial n).
link: Gus Wiseman, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20131
example: 1 is represented by the empty sequence (), by convention.
Successive rows of the triangle are as follows (c(k) denotes the k-th non-prime-power, A007916(k)):
This sequence represents a bijection N -> Q where Q is the set of all finite sequences of positive integers: 1->(), 2->(1), 3->(2), 4->(1 1), 5->(3), 6->(4), 7->(5), 8->(1 2), 9->(2 1), ...
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, Oct 20 2016
ext: Edited by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Nov 09 2016
